review_title: Amazing team, and a top-line that recognises the need to grow
pros: The people The development opportunities Wellbeing focus Annual leave entitlement Flexibility
cons: Caseload is all I can think of

pros: Really good group of people who are all trying to do a good job. They don't really check on you but you are expected to get through a lot o work
cons: Management is unavailable and really doesn't care. They let down the teams and students as their interest is money

pros: Flexible working and portfolio of products
cons: Lots of changes and communication needs to improve

review_title: Good individuals HINDERED by compensation and executives
pros: Our team in Scotland is excellent and supportive Our manager trusts us to do our job as he recognises our worth Even as a small team we have a large caseload overall and constantly reach and surpass goals and expectations regarding audits and EVs There are some very great individuals throughout the company who clearly want to do a good job but hindered by pay and/or support from higher-ups
cons: The pay is awful The rest of the company tend to completely forget Scotland exist, so many comms sent out only referencing to stuff relevant to England - it's very tiring The rest of the company constantly praised on goals that are pretty mediocre whereas we're doing really great things with hardly any recognition The higher-ups tend to restructure a lot and it never seems to make sense, as if they made up a new executive title and given someone a load of cash for no real reason Colleagues in England tend to pass the buck quite a bit and the team structures and managers are confusing and can be unhelpful Takes far too long for any change, everything needs to go through however many levels of execs for silly reasons just to get a pretty underwhelming response After a year or so cost of living crisis the "pay rise" for those under 30k was a measly £1500 tacked on to their yearly income.... and not even given in one go, they gave £1k then 6 months later £500? Those under 30k who'll be feeling the cost the most get BARELY even 2% when the cost of living has risen approximately 11%

pros: Always been fair with me, good opportunity for development
cons: Knee jerk reactions to things happening

pros: Some great colleagues and clients
cons: Toxic culture with very poor executive team. Constant staff turnover is disruptive to learners but culture and pay are major issues that the company should invest in. A very untrusting environment where your face has to fit, your age matters and blame is the name of the game.

pros: Good friendly members of staff
cons: Not much room for progression

pros:
Some lovely people working at Babington and everyone seems to be in it for the right reason and wants to do a good job. 
The role depends on your manager and department really, like all places some are great and some not so good. 
Being able to work remotely is a positive and flexible working can be good if you can apply it in your role.
cons:
Money is the main decision maker which I understand as it is a business with shareholders but some of the decisions are not ethical and will at some point cause the business issues. 
Too few people in the roles required and far too many senior managers with bizarre job titles being paid high amounts.

pros: Flexible working as well as a virtual first approach. Health & wellbeing benefits. Working for a purpose led organisation that helps develop better futures for individuals, organisations and society
cons: Extent of remote work - limited office network at present, although there are plans to improve this

job_title: Candidate Engagement Resourcer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
Opportunities to progress within business.
Opportunities to upskill yourself with training
cons: No office space in Scotland

job_title: Head of Bids and Proposals in Liverpool, England
pros: I've worked at Babington for just over 9 months and the company truly lives to its values. People are caring, passionate and encouraged to be brave to help the company grow organically. Flexible Working has made a big difference to the work/life balance and there is always someone there to help you develop your skills and excel to new levels.
cons: I don't see any thus far.

review_title: No progress or pay increase opportunities
pros:
- flexible with working from home 
- friendly colleagues 
- 8.30-5 working hours
cons:
- no progression opportunities
- no pay increase opportunities
- no pay increase during annual review even if receiving good feedback

pros: A strong company to work for with big ambitions. A great bunch of people to work with. Great benefits program especially Babington engage which allows discounts, additional annual leave and access to discounted memberships. There is also a Health care program which is easily accessible. Overall I feel well looked after working for Babington and have done for over 5 years.
cons: Non that I have experienced.

pros:
Real family feeling
Supportive teams
Open door policy - at all levels 
Flexibility 
Work-life balance and wellbeing high on the agenda
Positive reward and recognition
cons:
High number of meetings at times
Christmas close down taken from holiday entitlement

job_title: Life Skills Coach in Stoke-on-Trent, England
pros: Excellent manager and good support
cons: High caseload and pay variance

review_title: Exciting Company with a Bright Future
job_title: Finance, Compliance and Administrative Director in Birmingham, England
pros:
Clear Strategy and Direction
Clear role responsibilities and accountabilities
Achievable deadlines
Ability to contribute to senior leaders
Autonomy within a clear framework
Flexible working - good work / life balance
Exciting future plans
Dynamic, innovative leadership
Great market positioning
Customer responsive
Exceptional employee welfare
cons: None that I can see!!

job_title: Business Development Manager in Bristol, England
pros: Flexible, great place to work, supportive management and team
cons: Nothing to mention under cons

pros: Benefits of working for an SME
cons: Travel to hq can be intensive

pros: Very structured organisation, have great visions, brilliant IT service, supportive with mental health issues, flexible working opportunity, knowledgable workers, great L&D training
cons: Very structured can be negative as very hierarchical decision making, apart from Bupa healthcare, not much benefits or rewards. Slow progression as at any other training providers

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Derby, England
pros: The people are nice. Operational staff are pleasant on general. There is always a nice local feel to the business even though they are National.
cons: Communication. They have improved over the past year since Covid believe it or not but general communication of process changes or direction can become confusing

pros: Team is friendly and welcoming.
cons: No scope for career progression. Not prepared to give employees salary reviews, despite dedication and hard work. No transparency from the senior leadership to the rest of the company. Would not recommend working here.

pros: Decent work life balance, reasonable health insurance perk.
cons: Inconsistent quality of managers, which can heavily impact experience

job_title: Candidate Attraction and Engagement Manager in Derby, England
pros: I emailed Babington directly to see if there were any opportunities prior to a role becoming available because of all the good reviews I had heard via word of mouth and all were true. I have been with Babington for just over three months and have never been a part of a company with such a dedication to continuous improvement and nurturing of their staff to better their employees, the company and first and foremost the learners and employers experiences.
cons: None that I have come across so far!

pros: Some good team members
cons:
Ridiculous amount of work 
Can only see the profit margin not the overall picture decide to abandon the the Quality Team as this was seen as an additional cost even though this was a changing environment. 
Very little support for anyone outside of the Senior Management Team.
My induction was to be put in a room and left until another member of staff came in. 
Staff turnover really high caused in part by the constant redundancies and restructuring to cut costs to line the Investors pockets.
Very Surprised that all support staff and Trainers  have any time to complete any work as there is a constant array of pointless meetings to attend that are not fit for purpose.

pros:
Open to new ideas
Ambitious organisation 
Strong Work Ethic 
Nice working environment 
Good opportunity to develop into new role if you are successful
cons: Owned by venture capitalists, and therefore focus is on immediate short term financial reward rather than sustainable long term growth. Have good ideas about opportunities to develop into new markets, but set unrealistic timescales and targets. Very aggressive in terms of revenue generation and dismiss employees very quickly if they are not performing.

job_title: Head of Client Engagement in Bristol, England
pros:
Great culture, where everyone feels empowered and able to influence change.
Supportive management, that manage their teams as individuals.
Positive employees that are passionate about what they do and care about what they do.
cons: I cant think of any.

pros:
Good internal progression opportunities
Increasing turnover
cons: Unfortunately with increasing turnover comes a decrease in quality. Babington are increasingly seeing their customers as "just another number", and are more concerned about funding than quality of service. Staff are stressed out due to unrealistic targets and this is making them snappy and irritable. Opportunities to progress depend on who your manager is and if they like you.

review_title: A professional workplace with a person-focused culture
job_title: Director of Quality and Service Standards in Birmingham, England
pros: A professional place where you quickly become part of the team and feel that your own development is focused on from induction point.   There is a clear structure in the team but it's not hierarchical and the open door policy is truly a reality here. Learners and customers are at the heart of everything that is done in the business.  A busy and positive environment.
cons: None that I can see at the moment

pros: I have been supporting The Babington Group with their recruitment needs for the last 3 years and I can honestly say they are my favourite client to work with. The HR team are fantastic, very professional and get things turned around quickly! The Babington Group are a great company to work for offering an excellent place of work, great management team and benefits.
cons: There are no cons, this company are brilliant!

pros:
Some really lovely staff
Freedom to work from home
Flexibility to manage own diary
1 Manager was amazing and supportive
cons:
2nd Manager very unsupportive, in the 10 months I was managed I never had any form of appraisal, or provided with any KPI’s.
If your face fits & Directors like you then you’ll do well.
Staff treat like numbers & not humans
Profit rules, regardless of learners

pros:
Great culture, can't believe the business bring all the employees in to hold a Communications Day.  Most businesses these days only do this for the manager.

Also have a talent management programme in place, they really invest in their employees.
cons: Some of the benefits could be better, but I know they are looking at them

review_title: Used to be good until Investors started calling the shots
pros: Some genuine people on the frontline that want to do a good job
cons:
Management only interested in figures and pleasing Investors.
Recruitment team only go for numbers and don't care there's nobody to cover the learners. 
No bonus scheme or incentives
Travel up to 120 miles to see learners then get hauled over the coals when expenses are high.

review_title: Not a positive culture as it used to be. A shame as the staff are committed .
pros:
Good sectors and national coverage. 

New COO very approachable.

My team was good .

A lot of pressure to perform no matter what.
cons:
Caseloads for Tutors too high and travel a challenge to see learners.

The culture is quite negative when it used to be good.

pros: They are a busy company with a lot of work. They support you a great deal. They look after their staff in regards to medical and on a HR basis.
cons: Not a lot of room for progression

pros: Well structured and supportive business, there is a clear ethos and drive to support effective growth and development of the teams
cons: None of note really good stuff

pros: Improvements are being put in place to encourage progression
cons: Some areas are becoming micro managed

job_title: Head of Vocational Training in Bolton, England
pros: Challenge, Variety of work, Projects, Change, People, Rewarding work
cons: Indint have any cons to report other than it was hard work but rewarding

pros: Very supportive environment good benefits and wages.
cons: Targets quite high for sector. Need to be more realistic

pros: Strong ambitious organisation, good people within the business, development opportunities within
cons: Ambitious targets, not always realistic,

pros: Great team, people and ethic
cons: Inherited habits that are hard to break

job_title: Enrolment and Induction Officer in Derby, England
pros: Good pay and benefits. Nice working environment
cons: There are none good place to work.
